multiSelect.otherAminosalicylates: Other Aminosalicylates, including Pentasa®, Asacol®, Salofalk®, Mezavant®, and generics
multiSelect.antiTnfs: Anti-TNFs, including Infliximab (Remicade®,  Inflectra®, Remsima®), Adalimumab (Humira®), Golimumab (Simponi®)
multiSelect.smallMolecules: SMALL MOLECULES (including Jak Kinase Inhibitors), Tofacitinib (Xeljanz®)

pregnant.medications: Inhibits folate synthesis. Women taking this medication should also be taking higher folic acid supplements (2 – 3 mg per day) throughout pregnancy

preconception.medications: Inhibits folate synthesis. Women taking this medication who are hoping to conceive should also be taking higher folic acid supplements (2 – 3 mg per day)

aminosalicylatessulfasalazine.breastfeeding: Passage into the breastmilk in such small amounts that there is minimal concern.
aminosalicylatessulfasalazine.vaccinations: All usual vaccinations, including live vaccines can be given.
aminosalicylatessulfasalazine.infections: No known impact on infant risk

aminosalicylatesotherAminosalicylates.breastfeeding: Passage into the breastmilk in such small amounts that there is minimal concern.
aminosalicylatesotherAminosalicylates.vaccinations: All usual vaccinations, including live vaccines can be given.
aminosalicylatesotherAminosalicylates.infections: No known impact on infant risk

pregnant.medications: If you become pregnant while taking methotrexate, stop taking the methotrexate immediately and schedule an urgent appointment with your doctor or obstetric care provider. Notify your gastroenterologist as well, as they may have to find another medication

preconception.medications: Methotrexate can be harmful in pregnancy causing embryo malformation and fetal death. Discontinue use at least 3 months prior to trying to conceive (women and men).

methotrexateyes.breastfeeding: Most experts recommend not to breastfeed while on Methotrexate. If a decision is made to breastfeed, it is recommended to withhold breastfeeding for 24 hours after a weekly dose. Monitoring of the infant's blood count (CBC) could be considered.
methotrexateyes.vaccinations: All usual vaccinations, including live vaccines can be given, however most experts recommend not to breastfeed while on Methotrexate. If a decision is made to breastfeed, it is recommended to withhold breastfeeding for 24 hours after a weekly dose. Monitoring of the infant's blood count (CBC) could be considered.
methotrexateyes.infections: No known impact on infant risk, however most experts recommend not to breastfeed while on Methotrexate. If a decision is made to breastfeed, it is recommended to withhold breastfeeding for 24 hours after a weekly dose. Monitoring of the infant's blood count (CBC) could be considered.

pregnant.medications: Note allopurinol is not an immunosuppressant however may be used to help the action of azathioprine or 6MP. There is conflicting information surrounding the use of allopurinol in pregnancy, with some studies suggesting safety and others reporting fetal harm. Accordingly, while safety of use in pregnancy cannot be reassured, stopping allopurinol in pregnancy is not advised prior to consultation with your gastroenterologist.

preconception.medications: Note allopurinol is not an immunosuppressant however may be used to help the action of azathioprine or 6MP. There is conflicting information surrounding the safety of use of allopurinol in pregnancy, with some studies suggesting safety and others reporting fetal harm. Accordingly, while safety of use in pregnancy cannot be reassured, it is suggested you discuss with your gastroenterologist potentially revising the use of allopurinol prior to becoming pregnant.

allopurinolyes.breastfeeding: Exclusively breastfed infants should be monitored, including observation for allergic reactions (such as rash) and periodic blood count (CBC).
allopurinolyes.vaccinations: All usual vaccinations, including live vaccines can be given.
allopurinolyes.infections: No known impact on infant risk

pregnant.medications: Monitor maternal blood counts (CBC) monthly. It is recommended not to start during pregnancy (small risk of drug reaction, including pancreatitis).

thiopurinesIncludingyes.breastfeeding: The limited number of studies that have been done show that the amount of medication passed through breast milk is in very small amounts and it is acceptable to take while breastfeeding.
thiopurinesIncludingyes.vaccinations: All usual vaccinations, including live vaccines can be given.
thiopurinesIncludingyes.infections: When thiopurines have been used in combination with anti-TNFs during pregnancy, there has been identification of a small increased risk of common infections in the infant, such as ear and upper respiratory tract infections within the first 12 months of life.

pregnant.medications: When anti-TNFs are used in combination with immunosuppressant medications, there may be a small increased risk of infection in the baby from birth to 12 months.

preconception.medications: There are no known concerns regarding fertility and conceiving while on an anti-TNF

biologicsantiTnfs.breastfeeding: Very little anti-TNF medication is secreted into breast milk and, even if it is present, it is considered unlikely to cause harm.
biologicsantiTnfs.vaccinations: Babies exposed to anti-TNF in utero should NOT receive LIVE vaccines for the first 12 months of life. All other vaccinations should be given.
biologicsantiTnfs.infections: When thiopurines have been used in combination with anti-TNFs, there has been identification of a small increased risk of common infections in the infant, such as ear and upper respiratory tract infections within the first 12 months of life.

pregnant.medications: There was limited information available at the time this resource was created. However, from what is available, no concerns have been identified.

preconception.medications: There was limited information available at the time this resource was created. However, from what is available, no concerns have been identified.

biologicsvedolizumab.breastfeeding: Very little Vedolizumab is secreted into breast milk and, even if it is present, it is considered unlikely to cause harm.
biologicsvedolizumab.vaccinations: Babies exposed to vedolizumab in utero should NOT receive LIVE vaccines for the first 12 months of life. All other vaccinations should be given
biologicsvedolizumab.infections: There was limited information available at the time this resource was created. However, from what is available, no concerns have been identified.

pregnant.medications: There was limited information available at the time this resource was created. However, from what is available from the use in IBD and other conditions such as psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis, no concerns have been identified.

preconception.medications: There was limited information available at the time this resource was created. However, from what is available from the use in IBD and other conditions such as psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis, no concerns have been identified.

biologicsustekinumab.breastfeeding: Very little ustekinumab is secreted into breast milk and, even if it is present, it is considered unlikely to cause harm.
biologicsustekinumab.vaccinations: Babies exposed to ustekinumab in utero should NOT receive LIVE vaccines for the first 12 months of life. All other vaccinations should be given
biologicsustekinumab.infections: There was limited information available at the time this resource was created. However, from what is available from the use in IBD and other conditions such as psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis, no concerns have been identified.

pregnant.medications: There was limited information available at the time this resource was created. However, animal studies using very high doses of tofacinitib have shown harm to the foetus, therefore use when trying to conceive and in pregnancy is currently not advised. If you become pregnant while on tofacinitib, please contact your Gastroenterologist.

preconception.medications: There was limited information available at the time this resource was created. However, animal studies using very high doses of tofacinitib have shown harm to the foetus, therefore use when trying to conceive and in pregnancy is currently not advised.

smallMoleculesyes.breastfeeding: No information is available on the clinical use of tofacitinib during breastfeeding.
smallMoleculesyes.vaccinations: Insufficient information is available at the time this resource was created to advise regarding vaccination and exposure to tofacitinib.
smallMoleculesyes.infections: There was minimal information available at the time this resource was created.

pregnant.medications: Very small risk of tendon damage with ciprofloxacin if used in first trimester

antibioticsciprofloxacin.vaccinations: All usual vaccinations, including live vaccines can be given.
antibioticsciprofloxacin.infections: No known impact on infant risk

antibioticsmetronidazole.vaccinations: All usual vaccinations, including live vaccines can be given.
antibioticsmetronidazole.infections: No known impact on infant risk

antibioticsvancomycin.vaccinations: All usual vaccinations, including live vaccines can be given.
antibioticsvancomycin.infections: No known impact on infant risk

pregnant.medications: There is a small risk of cleft palate development associated with steroid use in the first trimester. There is also additional associated risks including gestational diabetes, but the risks of not using steroids with active disease are usually higher than taking steroids to control active disease. Suggest discussion with your obstetrician and gastroenterologist as there may also be the options of steroid sparing medications such as biologics.

preconception.medications: No known concerns. However, it is recommended for you to be in remission on stable maintenance medication for at least 3 months prior to attempting to conceive.

steriodsprednisone.breastfeeding: At doses >20 mg, delay feeding 3-4 h after dose
steriodsprednisone.vaccinations: All usual vaccinations, including live vaccines can be given.
steriodsprednisone.infections: In the first 4 months of life, there is a potential for small increase in infection

pregnant.medications: Limited information regarding use in pregnancy. Use in pregnancy is considered safe from available information.

preconception.medications: No known concerns. However, it is recommended for you to be in remission on stable maintenance medication for at least 3 months prior to attempting to conceive.

steriodsbudesonide.vaccinations: All usual vaccinations, including live vaccines can be given.
steriodsbudesonide.infections: No known impact on infant risk

pregnant.medications: Preferential use of hydrocortisone is recommended due to how the placenta metabolises steroids.

preconception.medications: No known concerns. However, it is recommended for you to be in remission on stable maintenance medication for at least 3 months prior to attempting to conceive.

steriodsintravenous.breastfeeding: Limited transfer of methylprednisolone into breastmilk; to minimise exposure, delay feeding 2 to 4 hours after dose. There is no data to support hydrocortisone use.
steriodsintravenous.vaccinations: All usual vaccinations, including live vaccines can be given.
steriodsintravenous.infections: No known impact on infant risk

feedback.option1: Likelihood of my baby being exposed to any drug during in utero development.
feedback.option2: Likelihood my baby being born with detectable drug in their bloodstream?
feedback.option3: The possible need to start steroids during pregnancy due to active IBD
feedback.option4: The risk my IBD will flare during pregnancy
feedback.option5: The possible need to start or restart a stopped medication due to active IBD
feedback.option6: Exposing my baby to a medication for which we only have limited information on safety for pregnancy (for example, small number of patients who have received the medication in pregnancy or short duration of follow up of infants)
